DeregistrationReasonOtherText: regulated substances fell below threshold standards

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Golden State Vintners (GSV) Reedley Plant adheres to an
overall company policy of maintaining a sound safety program to prevent or minimize accidental
toxic exposure to employees and the adjoining community.  The covered process in this facility
is a sulfur dioxide batch process.  Normal inventory in nine months of the year does not exceed
5,000 pounds.  In the last three months of the year, usage of sulfur dioxide is increased
necessasitating inventory as high as 12,000 pounds.  Liquid sulfur dioxideis is used to raise the
free and total sulfur levels in the wines for control of microorganisims and to provide gas to fill
tank headspaces for bacterial and oxygen control.  The completely manual operation involves
intermittent transfer of liquid sulfur dioxide from a one-ton holding cylinder into smaller
dispensers for addition to various wine batches.  All equipment used in the process is portable.  A
dedicated cylinder is provided to add sulfur dioxide to crushers during grape processing.

In view of this simple operation, only minor operating hazards are involved, predominantly
inadvertent bad connections that could be controlled by good operating and maintenance
practices.  The plant maintaines a written proceedure for handling sulfur dioxide and requires
periodic inspection and maintenance on cylinders and dispensers used at the facility.  Involved
operators are required to read and understand the Materials Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) prior to
initially handling sulfur dioxide and to use personal protective equipment (PPE) i.e. respirators,
gloves, etc. while transferring or dispensing.

Highlights of the off-site consequence analysis for the plant are as follows:

Worst case release (WCR) scenario is failure of one 2,000-pound sulfur dioxide vessel under
pressure of about 150 psig.

Alternative release (AR) scenerio involves damage of the sulfur dioxide vessel's main valve in a
partly-open position with an orifice diameter of one-quarter inch.

The sulfur diox

ide toxic endpoint is 0.0078 milligrams per liter (mg/l), equivilant to 3.0 parts per
million (ppm).

WCR takes place over ten minutes, with a distance to toxic endpoint of 3.14 miles and covers an
estimated population of 19,000.

Estimated AR distance to toxic endpoint is 0.63 miles and covers an estimated population of 320.

In the past five years, the plant has not experienced reportable accidental release of sulfur dioxide
at the facility.  Procedures for handling spills and immediate reporting to management are in
place.  These are embodied in a bound manual containing the release prevention and emergency
policies that the company is committed to uphold.

Plant management recognizes the need for a sound prevention program and emergency response
planning.  A management system has been set up to assign personnel within the plant
management for RMP implementation.  Other prevention program elements that are currently in
place are as follows:

Process information procedures.
Inspection and maintenance policy.
Communications and employee training.
Personal protection policy.
Confined space entry.
Onsite contractors hazard communication policy.
Process hazard review.
Hot work permits.
Energy control program - lockout guidelines.
Hazard evaluation for general work areas.
Accident investigation policy.

Although the facility is not planning any process and/or equipment changes in the foreseeable
future, a management of change policy will be set up for future implementation.

A written employee-participation plan regarding the elements of a process hazard review and its
recommendations will be set up.  Affected employees will be provided access to process hazard
documents and other information regarding the Plan's prevention program elements.

In-house compliance audits will be performed at least once every three years to verify that the
procedures and practices developed for the plan are adequate and are being followed.  A report
on audit findings will be prepared, app

ropriate responses to findings will be documented, and any
deficiency as a result of the audit promptly corrected.

The facility's emergency response program is documented as the Emergency Reaction Plan.  It
includes notification and coordination procedures with local fire department and police agencies
in emergency situation; a total plant evacuation plan; formation of the Emergency Reaction Team
made up of knowledgable personnel of plant's inner workings; and a pre-emergency plan
involving route review, evacuation drills, location and testing of emergency equipment, team
assignments, and shutdown procedures.
